reviewText: Brad Garrett is pretty good as the Great One. My only beef with this is that it really should have been a mini-series (i.e. HBO's "John Adams"). Jackie Gleason led a long, interesting life and it would have been nice to see an uncensored biopic that wasn't so condensed.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Brad does an excellent job doing Gleason and mimics his every expression.  You see how Gleason's inspiration seems to come from his earlier years and how he built off of others and recreated the best of the best. You'll enjoy this underated film and given the storyline of his life...it may have been too short of a movie, but does a respectable job none-the-less.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I enjoyed this movie and it captured the time period perfectly.  Brad Garrett is in top form as Gleason and you truly get the essence of the man.  My one complaint is that this movie really sanitized his life making the portrait incomplete.  Gleason was known to be exceptionally generous and also could be unbelievably cruel, neither of which this movie conveyed in full form.  But there is no gripe about the acting, which is five stars all the way around.  But this film only scratches the surface of the life and  complexity of the man who was known and loved as "The Great One"
Title: N/A

reviewText: Brad Garrett portrays The Great One, Jackie Gleason. Jackie wanted to be a funny guy from a young age... but he wan't a natural. This is where his genius came in... Gleason BECAME the Great One. His start as an emcee and his rounds in the clubs helped him to develop his comedic talent until he was ready for the new medium of television. He was the right person at the right time in the right place (with the right agent!). However, Gleason had his own personal demons which effected his relationships with others.The acting of all the characters in this DVD is great, but Garrett is awesome in this. I've only ever seen him in Raymond and had no idea of what a really great actor he is. This is a terrific movie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Known for his big brother rll on Raymond I never thought I would see such a stunning performance. H studied every nuance og gleason and he played it perfectly.This is best effort since Raymond. Get it...it is great.
summary: ALWAYS A GREAT FAN OF BRAD
Title: N/A

reviewText: Brad Garrett's portrayal of Jackie Gleason is so convincing that for most of this TV movie we forget it's a "TV movie", which tend to play a little superficially. My only criticism of his acting is that it lacked energy. He seemed to have paid serious attention to the Great One's mannerisms and expressions but once the cameras started to roll, he apparently forget to inject real bouyant Life into the mix.I do not agree that Kristen Dalton's Alice is impressive. Audrey Meadows was a great actress who was also funny. Dalton's take is purely "feminist"-aggressive in the modern sense [not that there's anything wrong with that] but Meadows tempered it with the underlying, inescapable truth that she deeply loved this man. To use an over-used noun, Meadows' decidely ahead-of-her-time feminism was "nuanced" and filled with pathos. For the historians, it appears that her 1952 audition is not exactly scripted accurately here.The movie ends with a 1980s interview, apparently based on the "60 Minutes" telecast. Garrett's Gleason says he wishes that he did another Honeymooners season. Although it's been written that Jackie did consider doing new episodes in 1959, most evidence I've read is that he was secure in closing down the spin-off (39) filmed shows: the ratings were disappointing *and* the quality was so remarkable that he knew another season could only bring disappointment.Perhaps some mention should have been made of Gleason's *versatility*: his composing and conducting; drammatic acting, etc. If the producers wanted to focus in on the The Honeymooners first go-'round in the '50s, may I point out another omission: I feel that many fans do not know that Jackie did not win an Emmy for those "Classic 39" - it went to Phil Silvers.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Brad Garrett does a convincing job of portraying Jackie Gleason.  This movie is heartbreaking in some ways to see a man with talent and drive go in a direction where he drives others and eventually himself into the ground.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Basically, Gleason was portayed as an SOB. And the truth is probably somewhere in the middle. It is very difficult to do a good tv bio pic because the talent used to portray the subject is NEVER AS GOOD AS the original. Stick with facts. This film did not nor do many. Like most TV biographies this one is simply okay. The best ones are probably David Cassidy's, The Osmonds, Bogie and the Beach Boys second bio-film, Judy Garland bio, Ray, James Dean (TNT). The others like "Bud and Lou" portray Lou Costello as a bitter, angry comedian (even before the death of his son) "Martin and Lewis" was embarrassing because the actors bore little or no resemblance to Martin and Lewis, The Three Stooges, The Temptations and Take Me Home: The John Denver Story were okay but the chronology in which events were re-created was in error. The Karen Carpenter Story was sanitized by the family beyond all rationality. "Liberace: Behind the Candelabra" was too dark and lurid beyond one viewing, "Walk the Line" was not convincing enough for me to believe I was watching Johnny Cash. Why was it necessary to do a "fictional account" of the life of Phil Spector HBO? JFK > Yecch! Whats the point? Probably one of the worst was "Crime of the Century," talk about fictionalizing Lindbergh history! I have no doubt that it is extremely difficult to re-create what took the original actors/musicians decades to perfect - for me it gets to be a bit embarrassing if it's not done well for not entertainment and most importantly...the historical record.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie is a very true to life biography of Jackie Gleason. Brad Garrett captures the essence of  Jackie Gleason. Jackie had a very dark side from other biography's I've read. This movie never hid those sad experiences.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The reviewer who said Gleason's life was sanitized was correct.  I saw the entire miniseries on TV and it glossed over Gleason's hard drinking and his mean side.Also, iirc, it glossed over Gleason's huge interest in UFOs.  Gleason actually had a house built upstate that looked like a UFO.  And Gleason swears that he was taken to Area 51 by Ike and saw aliens in a deep freeze.A UFO house wasn't the only unusual thing Gleason built.  Gleason was a notoriously heavy drinker - but could still quote Shakespeare when blotto - and hung out at Toots Shor's bar in NYC.  When he started broadcasting from Miami Beach, he had the entire Toots Shor's bar dismantled, shipped to FL and rebuilt backstage at his set.  He even had Toots Shor himself flown down to mix his drinks.Gleason was quite a guy and Brad Garrett captures him well.  But this show WAS definitely sanitized.  The Great One would not be amused.
summary: Brad Garrett is Great, but "Sanitized" is correct
Title: N/A
